title: Mapping Nanoscale Anisotropic Thermal Expansion and Strain through Correlative Diffraction, Imaging, and Spectroscopy in the TEM
content: Controlling the thermomechanical response of materials at the nanoscale can tailor electronic and optical device properties and prevent mechanisms of catastrophic failure. Scanning TEM electron energy-loss spectroscopy (STEM-EELS) thermometry has previously been used to map temperature, thermal expansion, and strain at sub-nanometer length scales [1-3]. Similarly, four-dimensional (4D)-STEM has been used to map sub-nanometer strain in materials [4,5]. In this work, we correlate TEM imaging, diffraction, and EELS of a freestanding, (100)-oriented Si thin film to quantify anisotropic thermal expansion and strain in three dimensions. The EEL spectra are calculated fully ab initio, which allows us to understand the many-body interactions that shift the volume plasmon mode with temperature.
